document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Social Studies

DE1D1104EB2C4AED9B7EF48D84261EAB.description:
Engage with images of modern communication systems
and communication systems from the past.

E9CD34BC37B94BA6A70612C6A775AED5.description:
Define global communication systems as the use of
technological innovations to share information
across borders.

D4C6AEC7CDA7407CAC81E39DB7714765.description:
Define global trade as the exchange of goods and
services between countries marked by specialization
and interdependence.

9FD0944EF3084FFBACAE117EC08196B4.description:
Discuss how global communication systems have
changed how people share information.

BF26A5C761BF41369DD3CBF719E62B39.description:
Discuss how global trade has improved consumer
access to international products.

9731C9E7F3FE4D02B5BC01CC26029F65.description:
Sequence
global trade and
communication
systems that
reduce the
effect of time on
the distribution
of goods,
services and
information.

288EDDB8AC5443F0AE7FB5743F497BE6.description:
Identify
the effect of a given
cause of global trade
that reduces the effect
of time on distribution
of goods, services
and information.

C195BA0416E543A4B466F7C463F5934C.description:
Compare
and contrast
communication
systems to reduce
the effect of time
on distribution of
goods, services
and information.

88C5D79965BC48CD8B2E79D669A1E56C.description:
Global trade
and communication systems
reduce the effect of time on
the distribution of goods,
Services, and information
(e.g., sustainability of
perishable foods, online
brokering versus personal
brokers, Internet access
versus library access).

C591CA0CDAB34A08BB1184D449F2DC0D.description: Engage with items labeled as produced in other countries.

BF6F3CED0CA6472881EB1F7D3A54499F.description:
Use a world map to identify origin of items produced in
other countries.

C168C0ADAFF7473E854F5CA2EF63842E.description:
Explain why people in Ohio purchase items imported from
other countries (e.g., reduced prices, resources local to
other country, agricultural climate).

917313AD64C249DF9FD7894FEA27A7B5.description:
Understand that there are economic risks and
benefits for countries participating in global trade
because they become interdependent.

3A0468399D644DE7B573EAFB362928C0.description:
Match the
consequences
of globalization
with its area of
impact (cultural,
economic,
physical, or
political).

F7B2163EEEE2472F8DFC8CBBC5A65AE2.description:
Summarize the
consequences
(cultural,
economic,
physical, or
political) of
globalization.

2775B8794FFE43CAB7133C96D0AEEC98.description:
Globalization has
cultural, economic, physical,
and political consequences
(e.g., Internet access
increases availability of
information, outsourcing leads
to regional unemployment,
development impacts local
ecosystems and economies,
computer hacking into
sensitive databases leads to
insecurity).

F3D149F7F2824FA690848563EAF477F3.description:
Engage with different geographic representations of
the world.

1930AFBE5CAB4C32AAB29DD8B4B52E6A.description: Locate different countries on a world map or globe.

B80C9F56EA934D3991BD95EF0640A8DE.description:
Define globalization as the development of an increasingly
integrated world economy marked by the international
trade of products and sharing of ideas.

9D2779A62B49488CA778BD91F14606FE.description:
Understand that countries may participate in political
organizations to help prevent and settle disputes that may
arise as a result of globalization.

43C9AD2966884921A3CBF33143511488.description:
Match an impact
on globalization
on whether it is
cultural,
economic, or
political.

4F0ACA80A1164D3AA07F1481CD96DCF6.description:
Identify an impact
of globalization on
cultural, economic,
or political ideas.

2F113DC2DE0846BAA57C3CF142818B9A.description:
Summarize the
consequences
(cultural,
economic,
physical, or
political) of
globalization.

7828ED49B5E44717B7CFC5BB5498793F.description:
Globalization
has shaped new cultural,
economic and political ideas
and entities (e.g., universal
human rights, European
Union, terrorist networks).

40C894B1BF114FF793AC683F8999AC1A.description: Engage with maps of the world showing major population centers.

1CDA68FE15664B8A9E24016381C84A1B.description:
Compare maps of the world showing major
population centers with satellite images of the Earth
at night.

2EDF7E1459F24EBCBB4F4786DBB41E71.description:
Understand that people live in urban, suburban, and
rural areas.

09ED5805665B4C23B55DED00A170B45B.description:
Use maps of the United States and the world to
identify urban, suburban, and rural regions.

6065D85D2B584913B1C0A8EE1F461C6D.description:
Define urbanization as the population shift from rural to
urban residency, the increase in the proportion of people
living in urban areas, and the ways in which each society
adapts to this change.

E87523E51FF64652B33D981D3DD95F98.description:
Identify a pro
or a con of
urbanization.

7A67A32113904137A57F54824E010B5C.description:
Explain
urbanization (who,
what, where, when,
how/why).

1ECD8ED6AAFD49348D122F13A698A690.description:
Compare and
contrast the
pros and cons
of urbanization.

EEE768B3DDE947B2BFBFB91D39E61EE0.description:
Urbanization
provides opportunities and
challenges for physical and
human systems in cities and
their surrounding regions
(e.g., development of
suburbs, loss of habitat,
central markets, squatter
settlements on city outskirts,
regional specialization in
services or products, creation
of ethnic enclaves).

8274845E41094AB084ACF9A0857CE3CC.description:
Engage with maps of the world showing major
population centers.

D193839AA4104C48A7A7BE9BA267B836.description:
Compare maps of the world showing major
population centers with satellite images of the Earth
at night.

B2C57B517197401B9AA7392C2796787F.description:
Define regions as areas of the world having
definable characteristics, but not always fixed
boundaries.

E458077F1490485597D905C0C20F3004.description:
Define patterns of human settlement as repeated or
expected ways that settlements grow (urbanization:
people settle near water, settlements grow into cities
grow near water, people migrate from rural areas to
cities).

7B294120D5CC4CD8A29E188B815B7930.description:
Understand that people live in urban, suburban, and
rural areas.

A42BA81991144AE9B0A984A24047DAEF.description:
Use maps of the United States and the world to
identify urban, suburban, and rural regions.

4CA0316EB34449DB9F698FF336845571.description:
Identify ‘human’ characteristics in the local
region that have changed over time
(urbanization, ethnic communities).

FB32FEF795B944BEB58F659C3C8EAF27.description:
Sequence two or
more settlement
changes in a
region over time.

087548EE269C4995B992F9ACAB149A5C.description:
Given
a pattern of human
development, identify
how that settlement
has changed over
time.

23424D4D348E427D85F96028C91342AE.description:
Evaluate patterns
of human
settlement over
time.

1DED097FE901434E98A64CF31A58910C.description:
Patterns of
settlement change over time
in terms of functions, sizes,
and spatial patterns (e.g.,
a canal town becomes an
industrial city, a rural area
becomes a transportation
hub, cities merge into a
megalopolis).

77B2F2DED1684CB397AD1D175B58E03D.description:
Engage with representations or examples of
human impact on the local environment, including
litter, playgrounds, parks, or farming.

3BC2B4EFF95646C2B024F881E5C4FFBE.description:
Engage with representations of human impact on the
environment (e.g., roads, dams, cities).

B09C05840F7C4CDAB59D288FBA072973.description:
Define regions as areas of the world having
definable characteristics, but not always fixed
boundaries.

CABDB5F46C074A178023191567417BA1.description:
Understand that geographic issues are concerns or crises
that involve the interactions of physical characteristics
and human activity

F365913926FC47EDBDAA3C5C8F053D87.description:
Discuss how changes in human activity (e.g.,
urbanization) or in the physical environment (e.g.,
pollution) influence those geographic regions creating
international issues.

A992AF0E6E7441F791D412B8639F5395.description:
Identify one way
that a region is
impacted by a
geographical issue.

C9CABE95654840DC87EB6DCF6E5C32F5.description:
Identify
ways that a region is
impacted by a
geographical issue.

36338834DB83417C875D6E3D7FA8C5EE.description:
Research and
explain how a
region is impacted
by geographical
issues.

F9DDAB74807548429070F347094E4230.description:
Regions are
used as a basis to analyze
global geographic issues
(e.g., desertification, political
disputes, economic unions).

85DF3A95D16145DB8E8885C0A8E892C4.description:
Engage with representations of the physical environment,
possibly through tactile interaction with water, soil, sand,
and rocks, and hot and cold air temperature, to connect
with the idea of different earth surfaces.

14C2138FA6FD4C4CB74DAFEC9976A453.description: Engage with geographic representations of world regions.

9785ED1997F649DAB5929E3A04DF2F22.description:
Define regions as areas of the world having
definable characteristics, but not always fixed
boundaries.

84AE04B702124F54A3AB838FE31BB78E.description:
Identify physical characteristics of regions using pictures
or other representations (desert, mountains, bodies of
water, forest).

B357AB9907D24601B5A98FFCA6D15C25.description:
Understand that the world can be organized into
regions using different characteristics like land
formations (mountains, desert), climate (polar,
temperate), or economic activities (industrial,
agricultural).

8076259F4E8D49F9BA757AC9CAB759A7.description:
Discuss how ‘human’ characteristics of a region, like
roads and bridges, can connect people within a physical
region like the Great Lakes region (e.g., multiple bridges
and tunnels connect Detroit to Windsor).

3829053C0D2C41A8971AF7525F71CA9E.description:
Identify human
or physical
characteristics of a
region.

4381FD352C29408CB072B6D2C65FE001.description:
Describe physical
and human
characteristics of a
region.

F39CAA433B194326ACF606BC9D48E13D.description:
Compare and
contrast the
interconnections
among physical
and human regions
the characteristics
of an identified
region.

36F1121E61544DA1987BEA3BE60D6D05.description:
There are
interconnections within and
among physical and human
regions (e.g., river systems,
transportation linkages,
common currency).

DE6CE68F75394247BA77276C6ED67CE4.description:
Engage with representations of the local community as
it has changed over time.

ED4036DD516D4A9E96D239E0EED1F87A.description:
Define regions as areas of the world having
definable characteristics, but not always fixed
boundaries.

1D648FB375F5493AAFD7012EB0949E35.description:
Identify characteristics of the local region that have
changed over time (urbanization, ethnic
communities).

B5D36956F5DA4DE59E7911079EDFF854.description: Identify a consequence of a change in the local region.

0EE0DAFB760441C1AED3090A4767A992.description:
Identify a change
that has occurred
in a given region
over time.

4F68E9CB87F6433CB0DF36D6EA154E8C.description:
Identify
changes that have
occurred in various
regions over time.

ECBB5D0072D348E7BA5925E1BFC03C2E.description:
Explain ways that
a region changes
due to human
activity (e.g.,
industrial belt to
rust belt, pristine
locations to tourist
attractions, colony
to independent
state)

231A0FD440284C819B9DC292B01440CD.description:
The
characteristics of regions
change over time and there
are consequences related to
those changes (e.g., industrial
belt to rust belt, pristine
locations to tourist attractions,
colony to independent state).

651704E1585E4390A7A31C7754283DB6.description:
Engage with representations of the physical environment,
possibly through tactile interaction with water, soil, sand,
and rocks, and hot and cold air temperature, to connect
with the idea of different earth surfaces.

A98BE051265C4D48BE92C817D7F802B9.description:
Define regions as areas of the world having
definable characteristics but not always fixed
boundaries.

4078DDBE7DCB43A1A34A04DDFD0351B8.description:
Identify physical characteristics of regions using pictures
or other representations (desert, mountains, bodies of
water, forest).

A640C8D490AF4C4EA8F427971307E1E0.description:
Understand that the world can be organized into
regions using different characteristics like land
formations (mountains, desert), climate (polar,
temperate), or economic activities (industrial,
agricultural).

239A026484C04A348470D8545C47FF7A.description:
Identify human
or physical
characteristics of
the local region.

79A1D73BF973484692AC7F0C41BC8139.description:
Describe physical
and human
characteristics of the
local region.

E3ED11828BB248E6A21B6E466FECC162.description:
Define the
characteristics
(formal,
functional, and
perceptual) of an
identified region.

2E73F77156C14608B44F4FF0F959C039.description:
Criteria are used
to organize regions and as the
criteria change, the identified
regions change (e.g., types of
economic activities, ethnic
groups, natural vegetation).

C57910D3EB1E4A03BA1702F855B02751.description: Engage with items labeled as produced in other countries.

0BEFD022281A48519DF554A380D0F2AE.description:
Use a world map to identify origin of items produced in
other countries.

D06D71A5F0924307B28F97391C64CEEF.description:
Explain why people in Ohio purchase items made in
other countries (e.g., reduced prices, resources local to
other country, agricultural climate).

C098259B72934758BAA7170D4016CD71.description:
Define interdependence as a mutual reliance between
two or more countries based on trade. Nations rely on
other nations for the goods they do not produce for
themselves.

3A04C834876C4E06BE2A80E4B669FC54.description:
Identify countries the U.S. relies upon to supply goods
we do not make or grow here (e.g., China, Mexico,
Germany, India, Brazil).

BD038E33E120408988F50890774ED442.description:
Identify items that
have been made in
another country.

87A20242E5D147E5BCC69301AC5D48BA.description:
Illustrate the
interdependence
using a common
product or business.
(e.g., vehicle made
from different parts
around the world).

E6E358085F29476094B14BE48AF21A5E.description:
Explain how
a commonly
used
product is
produced
used, and
supported
in different
parts of the
world.

89A7924D38264EF1AE92BC6C1EA682D9.description:
Activities
and patterns of trade and
communication create
interdependence among
countries in different
regions (e.g., seed corn
grown in Iowa and
planted in South
America, high-definition
televisions manufactured
in Japan and viewed in
the United States, news
outlets from many
countries available
around the world via the
Internet, instant access
to data affecting stock
markets in different
countries).

F46F5EA46E8A46A1BA40F9ADD8E3B18C.description:
Engage with individuals within school or community
who have immigrated or migrated into the local
community.

69CAAA30AF3E47A49CAC38BEBFEB3C90.description:
Identify migration as movement from one place to another
with the intention of settling in a new community.

62E1FFCD53584255B6DB0CD9DE1B7838.description:
Understand that humans migrating to a given area
impact the community in many ways.

16FA31AE85254F84B302DB4A5B2A9F47.description:
Identify some of the ways human migration impacts
communities where they settle (e.g., competition
for housing, jobs, and other resources; and sharing
of languages, religion and other cultural practices).

553D8AC9831A49CB83728EAC8CFF209D.description:
Identify an
impact of human
migrations to a
given area (e.g.,
road expansion,
new schools,
more
restaurants,
etc.).

6B41397A464B4142A9EBEF0B77744824.description:
Identify
several impacts of
human migrations to
a given area (e.g.,
road expansion,
new schools, more
restaurants, etc.).

D90C826AE9424662885F34393CD53110.description:
Explain the impact
immigration has
for a geographical
area (e.g., new
stores,
restaurants,
buildings, parks,
etc.).

FF9CE6842B674B5BB4F5E51E2D877E03.description:
Human
migrations impact physical
and human systems (e.g.,
stress on food supplies in
refugee camps, removal of
natural obstacles to
movement, harvest
productivity and migrant
labor, calls for an official
language in countries with
high immigration, reduction in
city tax revenues due to
urban emigration).

2DBBA70108934EBB83758D7052B10A77.description:
Engage with individuals within school or community
who have immigrated or migrated into the local
community.

90AC2408C5044BB08E318B246C8919D5.description:
Identify migration as movement from one place to another
with the intention of settling in a new location.

F2747B12BD254C27B0A4281B911066C0.description:
Recognize reasons people may choose to migrate to
a new location as push factors (drought, conflicts,
job opportunities).

47BDE55736794B54979798963D960C26.description:
Recognize reasons people may be attracted to certain
locations as pull factors (jobs, freedoms, safety,
available resources).

1BBD4E65FF824B46901249F525716253.description:
Identify a factor
that contributes to
human migrations.

2535690246F34005A1C543D3DE4C6995.description:
Describe
factors that contribute
to human migrations.

50FDB66BCBCA4D06B1381D3421085B99.description:
Research and
explain factors
that contribute to
human
migrations.

59AB6D7A7C3F45B9B27BDEF4F6ACAAE0.description:
Physical, cultural,
economic, and political
factors contribute to human
migrations (e.g., drought,
religious conflicts, job
opportunities, immigration
laws).

371074DECA5C49EA97F3D5ADAD468FCF.description:
Engage with images of various cultures interacting with
their environments focusing on a common human
need, such as shelter (e.g. all the different types of
houses).

6375BB06DDAA4E9C8D201D74FD2807D3.description:
Understand that culture is the common beliefs, values,
language, and traditions that a society shares.

742B235364F344249BCA09EB7A1CBA41.description:
Understand that technological resources consist of
information, tools, and products that humans create
to meet the needs of society (e.g., creating a spear
from wood and stone).

E0B934D4DB9A472FA612779E5785B9A0.description:
Understand that cultural beliefs may impact how humans
interact with animals (e.g., Hindu belief that cows are
sacred limits the consumption of beef in India).

AB26E91633A04B478205ECD42DE2A035.description:
Understand that technological resources may impact how
humans interact with the environment (e.g., tractors allow
farmers to increase the amount of land they farm).

3B5B3C6454874219A3466722EB107B11.description:
Match a cultural
characteristic or
technological
resource and
how it is
affected by
human
interaction
(e.g., plowing
with oxen vs.
plowing with
tractors).

365B605D5CC04FC68CB88CBD7988D5D9.description:
Identify a
cultural characteristic
or technological
resource that is
affected by human
interaction.

311B66B9ECDD4C6B86BD139DBE05851B.description:
Research
how human
interactions within
the environment
are affected by
culture and by
technological
resources.

BCB1C18B7D8149BDB4C7FEB211617B98.description:
Human interaction
with the environment is
affected by cultural
characteristics and
technological resources (e.g.,
plowing with oxen or with
tractors, development of water
resources for industry or
recreation, resource
conservation or development).

B68AC65772FD441ABE9FF334EB476141.description:
Engage with making a personal decision by listing the pros
(benefits) and cons (costs).

FEF9504FFF5945988577BA764F7B6FCE.description:
Engage with representations of people using
non- renewable resources.

F964EFCC2C0047708A040CE3E2CFEEDB.description:
Understand that renewable resources can be replenished
if not overused (e.g., trees).

BCBAB4B9CA1146078FA9218999DE68BD.description:
Understand that non-renewable resources cannot
be readily replaced once used (e.g., oil).

A477E8A38F844A62BE770E65F46CADA2.description:
Identify renewable and non-renewable resources in the
local environment.

2C56065CB86940DC9A1CB2FA3FC80A58.description:
Discuss possible costs (negative outcomes) of
over-using non-renewable resources.

152D1CFE53F94DABA64ED5B11E48A624.description:
Identify resources
that are renewable
and nonrenewable.

93066D1C6CB74A2EA747B6203E6C0A4A.description:
Match a
renewable and nonrenewable resource
with its cost or benefit.

B5E28CD8678A400DA9646D810F12904B.description:
Compare and
contrast the costs
and benefits of
using renewable
and non-renewable
resources.

8D9B361CE7B2491DA007DDBFB6B29FCB.description:
There are
costs and benefits of using
renewable, non-renewable
and flow resources (e.g.,
availability, sustainability,
environmental impact,
expense).

9E4C296BDFE14928814155C762937937.description:
Engage with representations people using
renewable resources.

E007F6E239C74854A47D6BD2D3848C3B.description:
Understand that renewable resources can be replenished
if not overused (e.g., trees).

91DDAC445058456BA0494B1566355161.description:
Understand that non-renewable resources cannot
be readily replaced once used (e.g., oil).

1CAA9DE0687448D89CF1602B138DB828.description:
Understand that different resources are available
in different parts of the world.

74FDF7B98F4C41CAA19803E87E1764C1.description:
Identify resources
that are renewable
and nonrenewable.

CC7FFE6322D649DC808A3F075417B4A5.description:
Distinguish between
renewable and nonrenewable resources.

DB358F675B9F49418A63CACBA1EE30BF.description:
Identify ways
renewable and
non-renewabl
e resources
are used by
people.

0375015D2E334F33B00C36D98B24E850.description:
Physical
processes influence the
formation and distribution of
renewable, non-renewable
and flow resources (e.g.,
tectonic activity plays a role
in the formation and location
of fossil fuels; erosion plays
a role in the formation of
sedimentary rocks; rainfall
patterns affect regional
drainage patterns).

AE92D995A2D448408DE27360FFDB5351.description:
Engage with representations of people interacting
with natural features in the environment.

63A4194FDCC8439589875A9F8BFFBBFB.description:
Sort representations of natural environment and human
modifications of the environment.

A3ED735D4BEA4C0EA38C33159B0EDC5E.description:
Understand that societies meet their needs in
different ways depending upon the local environment.

7415CFE586AE428497DBCC5B61ACFB6F.description:
Recognize that opportunities in the environment
are favorable features (e.g., waterfall, coal, river)
that societies can use to meet their needs.

C0AF8B94E6C44515A55D08049270FD86.description:
Recognize that constraints in the environment are
features (e.g., desert, flood zone, steep mountains) that
societies have to adapt to in order to meet their basic
needs.

4B9373363D71420DA1C108E9E6C7172B.description:
Match representations of features the physical
environment with representations interacting with the
features (e.g., lake and fishing boat, forest and log
cabins, plains and farms).

EA28CA28DFAE426191CE2B7787591EC9.description:
Identify a potential
adaptation to a
physical
environment (e.g.,
solar panel,
hydroelectric
plant).

894F58A8F3E54788936434165A1939FB.description:
Identify
one way a society
has adapted to an
opportunity or
constraint
presented by the
physical
environment.

E74993FF2FEB4B6C942DB67F7A053B41.description:
Describe ways
society has
adapted to an
opportunity or
constraint
presented by
the physical
environment.

EDB88CB6E9EB490BB7A429D72D4D5899.description:
Human societies
use a variety of strategies
to adapt to the opportunities
and constraints presented
by the physical environment
(e.g., farming in flood plains
and terraced farming,
building hydroelectric plants
by waterfalls and
constructing hydroelectric
dams, using solar panels as
a heat source and using
extra insulation to retain
heat).

BAD85AEEBB724527BE2B6E9DA54D4717.description:
Engage with representations of human environmental
modifications, such as dams, highways, construction
sites.

D945C0BD6F8B4295B214D5F22D3632BD.description: Identify human changes in the local community.

4E14F9A737FE464CBA78C8787E9CF53C.description:
Discuss how a change in the school or local community
can lead to other changes in the school/ community -
some changes may be in areas that were unexpected.

E1C38BC3415D4440BAD85B36F902CE35.description:
Define physical environment as the natural world
(land, air, water, plants and animals) and human
construction (buildings, roads, dams).

E34957258CAB4C4AB83AC558D1FC4CF5.description:
Understand that human actions can change the physical
environment in expected and unexpected ways.

1E5E702FAAF34B8393020F866C9BB878.description:
Identify ways changes to the physical environment
can impact people with disabilities.

FF2A64720C0F4645A2A54FC39C3D664C.description:
Given a human change to the physical environment,
predict possible changes elsewhere (e.g., the next
town, further down the road).

7AA335A55849498C85A135ECF2C77D37.description:
Identify human
modifications that
can change the
environment (e.g.,
highway, factory,
dam).

EAE7241304794CFCA57EB9C80663DBC8.description:
Identify
human changes to
the environment in
one area that led to
change in another
area.

8A798D347B3D4103BD2F2B36BD19EFF7.description:
Describe human
changes to the
environment in
given areas that
led to changes in
other areas.

394C2296E3B440C3989146BAF235AF96.description:
Human
modifications of the physical
environment in one place
often lead to changes in other
places (e.g., construction of a
dam provides downstream
flood control; construction of
a city bypass reduces
commercial activity in the city
center; implementation of dry
farming techniques in a
region leads to new
transportation links and
hubs).

44D318128BF24E18A4C2B301E877EC6F.description:
Engage with various forms of maps (e.g., political,
relief maps, satellite images, topography map, road
map, bus map).

1DF1E78D40CE4A619B25CD8ED4DE7CB3.description:
Engage with multiple forms of geographic
representations (e.g., maps, globes, Internet-based
maps, global positioning systems).

A1CA152E7C2D4383BC61915349550A77.description:
Understand that an example of geospatial technology are
Internet-based mapping applications (e.g., Google
maps).

40D53FF72A05477C8573E692E38E3A92.description:
Understand that geographic representations can be
used to solve problems, such as school bus routes or
traffic congestion.

FDF19782F39D45C49EC19699B3F0F770.description:
Use a map of the local community to solve a problem,
such as finding the safest route to a desired location.

98CE2EB7E5D7491492D9B6DD669932FF.description:
Match
the geographic
representation or
geospatial
technology with a
device that
supports it (e.g.,
GPS in car or
phone).

E8CEAFD8AB5D42A9A4DC97D2479934BA.description:
Identify the purpose of
a geographic
representation or
geospatial technology.

48EC9F4140C04A079D5F677948B77733.description:
Compare
and contrast
geographic
representations
and geospatial
technologies to
investigate their
purposes.

AB20C5268BCF40BF8FCE4B28B5957A68.description:
Geographic
representations and
geospatial technologies are
used to investigate, analyze,
and communicate the results
of geographic problem-solving.

67BDAE23D7C74095AD8BDB324F1D3CF6.description:
Engage with various forms of maps (e.g., political,
relief maps, satellite images, topography map, road
map, bus map).

DB049BC5A0914F768E964A3A076045A4.description:
Engage with multiple forms of geographic
representations (e.g., maps, globes, Internet-based
maps, global positioning systems).

940E90239FD947F196DC695549DFF27D.description:
Locate emergency exit map in the classroom and practice
the route.

166E81D99B564EDF86F2E31584F193B5.description:
Utilize a map of the school or local community to get
from one place to another.

DB0EACAB1E35410480204E89B7EC70EB.description:
Understand that different geographic representations are
used for different purposes.

36A514133F2445CDA2318560B657FAE9.description:
Recognize and use features of maps (e.g., compass
rose, key or legend, scale, title).

888128DDE5A04198B4F9B317CAD0B2C6.description:
Sort
maps based on
their purpose.

997234EB5E924BCA91B408ACC03AC81F.description:
Identify
the properties and
functions of a specific
map to determine its
purpose (e.g.,
weather, location,
store locations, bus
line).

865E9A5123F84F04B757CE21802C2E9C.description:
Define
the properties and
functions of a
geographic
representation
(e.g., maps,
globes, graphs,
diagrams, Internetbased mapping
applications,
geographic
information
systems, remote
sensing,
geographic
visualizations).

F79F6088F4E04B8DA618C6573EA0F56F.description:
Properties and
functions of geographic
representations (e.g., maps,
globes, graphs, diagrams,
Internet-based mapping
applications, geographic
information systems, global
positioning systems, remote
sensing, geographic
visualizations) affect how
they can be used to
represent, analyze, and
interpret geographic
patterns and processes.
